"**_Miami Vice_ Theme**" is a musical piece composed and performed by [Jan
Hammer](/wiki/Jan_Hammer "Jan Hammer") as the theme to the television series
_[Miami Vice](/wiki/Miami_Vice "Miami Vice")_. It was first presented as part
of the television broadcast of the show in September 1984, was released as a
single in 1985, and peaked at the number one spot on the [_Billboard_ Hot
100](/wiki/Billboard_Hot_100 "Billboard Hot 100"). It was the last
[instrumental](/wiki/Instrumental "Instrumental") to top the Hot 100 until
2013, when "[Harlem Shake](/wiki/Harlem_Shake_\(song\) "Harlem Shake
\(song\)")" by [Baauer](/wiki/Baauer "Baauer") reached number one.[1] It also
peaked at number five in the UK and number four in Canada. In 1986, it won
[Grammy Awards](/wiki/Grammy_Award "Grammy Award") for "[Best Instrumental
Composition](/wiki/Grammy_Award_for_Best_Instrumental_Composition "Grammy
Award for Best Instrumental Composition")" and "[Best Pop Instrumental
Performance](/wiki/Grammy_Award_for_Best_Pop_Instrumental_Performance "Grammy
Award for Best Pop Instrumental Performance")." This song, along with [Glenn
Frey](/wiki/Glenn_Frey "Glenn Frey")'s number two hit "[You Belong to the
City](/wiki/You_Belong_to_the_City "You Belong to the City")", put the _Miami
Vice_ [soundtrack](/wiki/Soundtrack "Soundtrack") on the top of the US album
chart for 11 weeks in 1985, making it the most successful TV soundtrack of all
time until 2006, when [Disney Channel](/wiki/Disney_Channel "Disney
Channel")'s _[High School Musical](/wiki/High_School_Musical "High School
Musical")_ beat its record.

## Versions[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Miami_Vice_Theme&action=edit&section=1
"Edit section: Versions")]

  * The 1:55-minute version that aired with the pilot. The famous synthesized guitar lead hook is absent from it, and it features distinct synth guitar notes in its midsection.
  * The 0:57 version in the following 3 regular episodes, which only contains the percussion and keyboards, without the synth guitar hook. It was essentially a shortened version of the pilot, although it already featured the same melody progression and conclusion at its end as in all the later episodes.

According to Jan Hammer's manager Elliot Sears, the missing guitar lead hook
was the result of the sound elements not being mixed together as Hammer
intended.

  * The 1:00 synth guitar hook version that aired with all later episodes. It was first introduced at the end of the first regular episode, _Heart of Darkness_ , over the closing credits, albeit with the guitar hook slightly more muted than in future episodes.
  * The 2:26 full radio airplay version, the final 55 seconds of which are very similar to the 1:00 TV version.
  * An extended dance remix, released in 1985 as a 12" single containing two different length versions (in addition to the original version of the theme).

## Music
video[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Miami_Vice_Theme&action=edit&section=2 "Edit
section: Music video")]

The music video of the theme is a mini-episode of the TV series with Hammer as
a fugitive on the run from [James "Sonny" Crockett](/wiki/Sonny_Crockett
"Sonny Crockett") and Ricardo Tubbs. Throughout the majority of the video,
Hammer performs the theme in front of a projector screen playing footage from
the TV series – including scenes of the Vice duo chasing him. In the end of
the video, he boards a helicopter and escapes from Crockett's sight. The video
also shows shots of [Fairlight CMI](/wiki/Fairlight_CMI "Fairlight CMI")
screens including the page R (sequencer) page and the waveform page.

## Covers[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Miami_Vice_Theme&action=edit&section=7
"Edit section: Covers")]

[Alexi Laiho](/wiki/Alexi_Laiho "Alexi Laiho") and [Alexander
Kuoppala](/wiki/Alexander_Kuoppala "Alexander Kuoppala") of
[Finnish](/wiki/Finland "Finland") [melodic death
metal](/wiki/Melodic_death_metal "Melodic death metal") band [Children of
Bodom](/wiki/Children_of_Bodom "Children of Bodom") did a short [cover
version](/wiki/Cover_version "Cover version") of the theme on their 1997 album
_[Something Wild](/wiki/Something_Wild_\(album\) "Something Wild \(album\)")_.
The cover is a [hidden track](/wiki/Hidden_track "Hidden track") within their
song "Touch Like Angel of Death".

##
Appearances[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Miami_Vice_Theme&action=edit&section=8
"Edit section: Appearances")]

### Episodes[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Miami_Vice_Theme&action=edit&section=9
"Edit section: Episodes")]

_Miami Vice 's_ pilot episode, made as a two-hour TV movie, did not originally
have a theme, but the musical sounds and notation that would become the theme
were present as background score. When the series got picked up, Hammer
created the 60 second version of the theme. The synth-guitar lead was missing
in the aired version of the pilot and the first batch of episodes, and this
unfinished version of the theme has remained attached to those episodes, even
on the DVD video box set released in 2005.

###
Commercial[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Miami_Vice_Theme&action=edit&section=10
"Edit section: Commercial")]

The theme is also remembered as the song played during the first few three-
point competitions at the [NBA All-Star Weekend](/wiki/NBA_All-Star_Weekend
"NBA All-Star Weekend"), including the one in
[1986](/wiki/1985%E2%80%9386_NBA_season "1985–86 NBA season") where [Larry
Bird](/wiki/Larry_Bird "Larry Bird") famously walked into the locker room and
told all his competitors they were playing for second place.

### Radio[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Miami_Vice_Theme&action=edit&section=11
"Edit section: Radio")]

From 1992 until 1997, it was used as the theme music for [Westwood
One](/wiki/Westwood_One_\(current\) "Westwood One \(current\)")'s _Radio Free
D. C.: The[G. Gordon Liddy](/wiki/G._Gordon_Liddy "G. Gordon Liddy") Show_.
(From 1992 until 1996, an announcer would introduce the show during the music
bed, saying, "From Washington D. C., Radio Free D.C., with G. Gordon Liddy".)
Liddy had been a recurring guest on _Miami Vice_ during its run.

English radio presenter Paul Breeze adopted the tune to open his music shows
on Blackpool's Kit Kat Radio from 1996 to 1999 and, more recently, he re-
adopted the tune for Paul & Lucy's "Best Kept Secrets" show—featuring what's
on news and interviews for the Blackpool area—on internet radio station Fylde
FM during early 2010.

In the [Philippines](/wiki/Philippines "Philippines"), FM station
[DWFM](/wiki/DWFM "DWFM") or Radyo Singko 92.3 News FM use the music as the
background music for its morning news program "Punto Asintado" which is
presented by [Erwin Tulfo](/wiki/Erwin_Tulfo "Erwin Tulfo") and [Martin
Andanar](/wiki/Martin_Andanar "Martin Andanar").
